courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Foundations in Public Health
courses.description:
(UGEC1920 is double-coded with PHPC1001.)

This course will introduce undergraduate students to the discipline of public health and its basic academic framework, concept and methodology. The objective of the course is to provide a broad intellectual perspective of public health and presents both local and global public health challenges that are facing our society in the 21st century. The various academic disciplines within the domains of public health that include environmental health sciences, health policy and management, social and behavioral sciences and basic science will be introduced and discussed. The impact of these public health problems in relation to our society and our everyday lives will be emphasized. An analytic public health problem solving framework will be used to enable students to appreciate and learn the problem solving methodology in evaluating and appraising various public health problems.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
PHPC1001 is double-coded with UGEC1920.
Not for students who have taken MEDF1021, 1120, UGEC1920 or UGEC2930.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, the students should be able to:

1. Define public health, identify its major domains, functions, and disciplines, and explain its historical development and contemporary achievements.

2. Describe the concepts of transitions, and analyze the impact, challenges, and strategies for controlling infectious and non-communicable diseases.

3. Examine the impact of physical activity and sedentary behavior on fall risks in older adults and assess interventions promoting physical activity and health among school-aged children.

4. Describe the ethical principles in health and healthcare, including social and distributive justice

5. Analyze the social determinants of health and health equity, and evaluate population health and high-risk intervention strategies.

6. Describe the basic concepts of health demography and analyze the associations between population attributes and population health
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview and Foundation Concepts of Public Health

2. The Origins and Early History of Public Health

3. The Contemporary Achievements and Recent History of Public Health

4. Exercise is Medicine

5. Infectious Diseases

6. Physical activity and falls in older adults

7. Health System

8. Public Health Ethics and Justice

9. Health Equity

10. Social Determinants of Health

11. Population Health & Health Demography Current & Future Challenges
courses.feedback_evaluation:
1. Course and Teaching Evaluation Survey
2. Internal Course Review
courses.required_readings:
Week 1: Overview and Foundation Concepts of Public Health

Detels R, et al. Chapter 1.1 The scope and concerns of publilc health. Oxford Textbook of Public Health (5 ed.); 2011. Link: http://oxfordmedicine.com/view/10.1093/med/9780199218707.001.0001/med-9780199218707-chapter-0101

Week 2: The Origins and Early History of Public Health

Berridge V. Chapter 3. The origins of public health into the 1700s. Public Health: A Very Short Introduction; 2016. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Week 3: The Contemporary Achievements and Recent History of Public Health

Berridge V. Chapter 4. Sanitation to education: 1800-1900s. Public Health: A Very Short Introduction; 2016. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Berridge V. Chapter 5. The rise of lifestyle: 1900-1980s. Public Health: A Very Short Introduction; 2016. Oxford: Oxford University Press.

Week 4: Exercise is Medicine

Exercise is Medicine Hong Kong. Link: http://www.eim.hk/

Week 5: Infectious Diseases

Schneider M-J. Chapter 9: The “Conquest” of Infectious Diseases. Introduction to Public Health (5th edition). Jones and Bartlett Publishers; Massachusetts; 2016. Read: pp. 117-124.

Week 6: Physical activity and falls in older adults

Schneider M-J. Chapter 29: Public Health and the Aging Population. Introduction to Public Health (5th edition). Jones and Bartlett Publishers; Massachusetts; 2016. Read: pp. 469-481

Week 7: Health System

Leung GM, Bacon-Shone J, eds. Parts II & III. Organisational, Management, and Quality of Care Issues. Hong Kong’s Health System: Reflections, Perspectives and Visions. HK: Hong Kong University Press; 2006. Read: pp. 137-144

Week 8: Public Health Ethics and Justice

Campbell AV. Chapter 6. Justice. Bioethics the Basics. London & New York: Routledge; 2017. Read: pp. 137-159.

Week 9: Health Equity

Macintyre S. The Black Report and beyond: what are the issues? Soc Sci Med. 1997 Mar;44(6):723-45. doi: 10.1016/s0277-9536(96)00183-9. PMID: 9080558.

Week 10: Social Determinants of Health

Marmot M, Wilkinson RG. Chapter 1. Introduction. Social Determinants of Health (2nd edition). UK: Oxford University Press; 2006.

Marmot M, Allen JJ. Social determinants of health equity. Am J Public Health. 2014 Sep;104 Suppl 4(Suppl 4):S517-9. doi: 10.2105/AJPH.2014.302200. PMID: 25100411; PMCID: PMC4151898.

Week 11: Population Health & Health Demography

Rose G. Sick individuals and sick populations. Int J Epidemiol. 2001 Jun;30(3):427-32; discussion 433-4. doi: 10.1093/ije/30.3.427. PMID: 11416056.

Week 12: Current & Future Challenges/Final Recap

[Reread] Detels R, et al. Chapter 1.1 The scope and concerns of publilc health. Oxford Textbook of Public Health (5 ed.); 2011. Link: http://oxfordmedicine.com/view/10.1093/med/9780199218707.001.0001/med-9780199218707-chapter-0101

Schneider M-J. Chapter 31: Public Health in the Twenty-First Century: Achievements and Challenges. Introduction to Public Health (5th edition). Jones and Bartlett Publishers; Massachusetts; 2016.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Anatomy & Physiology: Essential Human Body Functions
courses.description: The course will cover the foundation concepts and basics of health science knowledge related to clinical medicine and specific to public health practice. It will provide an overview of basic knowledge from the molecular/cellular level to tissue, organ and organ system levels. The course will cover human physiology, anatomy, genetics as well as pathogenesis of diseases of public health importance. It aims to provide the foundation and essentials for understanding human body functions and the scientific basis in the design, rationalization and implementation of public health interventions.

courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe the fundamental concepts and principles of human anatomy and physiology as well as pathogenesis of diseases of public health importance of different body systems

2. Establish the links from basic health science, normal body functions, disease development and ultimately formulation of disease prevention and control public health strategies

3. Apply basic health science knowledge in the design, planning and implementation of public health programmes or initiatives
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Overview of basic human physiology and anatomy, organs and organ systems
2. Cells, tissues and genetics and case studies
3. Circulatory system and case studies
4. Neurological system and case studies
5. Human anatomy and physiology and public health interventions
6. Hematological system
7. Immune system
8. Case studies of hematological and immune systems
9. Interactive laboratory session on human anatomy

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Principles of Infectious Diseases
courses.description: This course provides an introduction to the causation, epidemiology and prevention and control of infectious diseases in a public health context. Essential microbiology and immunology would be included. Concepts of the relationship among agent, host and environment will be covered. Impacts of infectious diseases on society will be discussed. Illustrations will be given using both historical events and topical issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC1004.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:
1. acquire basic concepts and knowledge in microbiology, pathogenesis, immunity against infectious diseases in human
2. appreciate the clinical presentations and principles of management of infectious diseases
3. understand the principles and public health strategies for control and prevention of infections
4. understand the interactions between infectious diseases, society and the environment

Public Health Infrastructure of ID control 5. Infectious disease surveillance 6. Infection Control and Prevention 7. Host response to infection and use of vaccines |

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Introduction to Biostatistics
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic biostatistics concepts and their applications in health data analysis. Emphasis will be placed on conceptual understanding of statistical approaches to medical data rather than on theory and equations. Students will learn the importance of the correct use of statistical methods in addressing questions of public health importance. The course will involve hands-on practice using an Excel dataset to generate various statistical outputs such as histograms, scatterplots, boxplots, and two-by-two tables.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken -COMM3110, DSME2010,2020,2011,2021, ECON2121, GRMD2102, PHPC1015,2015, PSYC2010, SEEM2430, SOCI2004, SPED2600, STAT2101,2102,2001 or 2006
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:

1. Understand and differentiate between various levels of measurement (nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio) and their significance in statistical analysis.
2. Compute and interpret descriptive statistics, including measures of central tendency (mean, median, mode) and measures of variability (range, variance, standard deviation).
3. Conduct hypothesis testing using one-sample and two-sample t-tests, and interpret the results and p-values.
4. Perform chi-square tests for categorical data and analyse two-by-two tables.
5. Calculate and interpret confidence intervals for means and proportions.
6. Understand the concepts of Type 1 and Type 2 errors, and their implications in biostatistics.
7. Gain proficiency in using Excel to generate and interpret various statistical outputs, such as histograms, scatterplots, boxplots, and two-by-two tables.
8. Apply biostatistical methods to real-world health data and effectively communicate the results of their analyses.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to Biostatistics and Levels of Measurement
2. Descriptive Statistics
3. Sampling Distribution
4. Hypothesis Testing - One-Sample t-Test
5. Hypothesis Testing - Two-Sample t-Test
6. Chi-Square Test
7. Confidence Intervals

courses.recommended_readings: Bland, Martin. An introduction to medical statistics. Oxford University Press (UK), 4th Edition, 2015.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Nutrition for Health and Exercise
courses.description: This course provides the foundation background of nutritional science and its application to the primary prevention of diet-related illness and to maximize physical exercise outcome. It will look into the importance of nutrition throughout the lifespan and in different population sub-groups. The wide variety of nutritional issues in both developed and developing countries will be discussed. It explores the relationship of diet to athletic performance. Nutrition support for exercise and the appropriate use of sports supplementation will also be covered.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: MEDF1021or MEDF1120 or PHPC1001 or PHPC1012 or UGEC1920 or UGEC2930.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
| By the end of this course, students should be able to: 1. acknowledge the scope and the potential implication of the study of nutrition in relation to health and physical exercise; 2. demonstrate the basic scientific understanding of various foods and nutrients and their physiological functions; 3. obtain an understanding of the importance of nutrition throughout the lifespan and in different population sub-groups; 4. understand the role of nutrition in the prevention and management of various diet-related non-communicable diseases; 5. Demonstrate an understanding of sports nutrition and its application. |
| --- |

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Environment and Work

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 407

courses.description: This public health oriented course addresses how the environmental and occupational (work-related) factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. Whereas environmental science tends to address how human beings affect the environment, this course focuses on how the environment affects human health. Topics include an introduction to the toxicology and environmental epidemiology methods in assessing the impact of environmental exposures on human health; how the physical, chemical or biological agents in the air, water, soil and food affect human health; the evaluation and control of common hazards in the work place; and the impacts of global environmental changes on health.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CHPR2001
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:
1. Discuss the history and definition of environmental health and occupational health
2. Describe epidemiology, toxicology and risk analysis methods to evaluate the impact of environmental exposures on human health
3. Define the major sources and types of hazards in the environment and workplaces
4. Discuss the direct and indirect human health effects of major environmental and occupational agents
5. Discuss the general principles of environmental pollution mitigation and occupational hazard control
6. Discuss local, regional and international regulatory programs, guidelines and authorities on environmental and occupational health
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction

2. Exposure, dose and risk analysis

3. Environmental hazard and health impact

4. Natural environment and health

5. Work and health

6. Occupational disease and injury; Occupational legislation

7. Written assignment guideline//mid-term exam

8. Environmental health problems in Hong Kong

9. Environmental health for all: global issues and international treaties

10. Fundamentals of environmental epidemiology

11. Water and food safety

12 . Solid and hazardous waste

13. The atmosphere and air pollution

courses.title: Health Care System & Policy

meetings.instructor:
Professor WANG Kailu, 
Professor WONG Lai Yi

Professor WANG Kailu, 
Professor WONG Lai Yi

Professor WANG Kailu, 
Professor WONG Lai Yi

courses.description:
Healthcare systems are complex and multidisciplinary in nature. They need to meet population needs and may include a network of services such as prevention, diagnosis, treatment, rehabilitation, and
health maintenance provided to individuals of all ages and with a range of needs. Policy plays an important role in maximizing the function of health care systems. This course is an introductory course
on basic definitions and functions of health care systems. Using case studies and discussions, students will be able to develop understanding of policy and practice in health care.

courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:

1. Describe the basic concepts and functions of health system

2. Classify the healthcare delivery provision in different levels and its quality of care

3. Recognize different healthcare financing mechanism and its characteristics

4. Identify the basic elements of health policy and its impact on health care systems

5. Discuss different types of resources required in the health system

6. Compare and contrast how the contextual factors shape the health systems

2. Healthcare Services; Community Service Mode

3. Healthcare Resources & Long-term Care

4. Site Visits

5. History of Healthcare Services

6. Healthcare Financing

7. Health Policy I: Introduction

8: Health Policy II: Health Care Reform + Case Discussion

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Global Health
courses.description:
This course will introduce how public health principles may be applied to understand and examine health issues and initiatives in global settings.

Students will build up a knowledge base in global public health issues and will identify global health problems and devise possible solutions to these problems. Public health issues in specific countries will be identified and students will work in teams, develop critical thinking skills and expand their knowledge base in public health and provide possible solutions of global health issues. They will communicate their findings to each other and to the whole class in presentations. The contexts from which these public health issues arise in these countries would be compared
and contrasted.

The course would provide opportunities for development of relevant attributes by the use of issue-based teaching approaches e.g. students will be engaged in learning tasks which require them to analyze in depth of a global health issue of specified countries, appreciate the complex nature of dynamics which shape global health issues and agenda, understand various perspectives of the stakeholders (nations, governments, non-government body, civil society etc.) and demonstrate the values of global citizenship, and come up with possible solutions which include
defining goals, formulation of strategies/action plans, gathering and identification of resources needs and the skills to communicate with stakeholders.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite:PHPC1001 or MEDF1021 or UGEC1920 or UGEC2930
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, students will be expected to:

1. Be equipped with the knowledge base and skills to identify and analyze global health issues

2. Be aware of the contextual factors which come into play in global health issues and develop relevant attributes and skills to consider possible

solutions

3. Demonstrate the role and responsibility of global citizenships and how individual might be related to the protection of global health

4. Identify key stakeholders in global health and its underlying decision-making dynamics, and able to engage with them

5. Understand current trends and thematic issues in global health and arouse international awareness

6. Examine and discuss key health priorities such as SDGs, Sendai Framework, Urban Agenda and Paris agreements in a global environment

7. Have divergent and convergent thinking to formulate solutions to address the global health challenges
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Introduction to Global Health
2) Global Burden of Disease: Non-Communicable Diseases & Communicable Diseases
3) Global Health Policy and Governance
4) Poverty Reduction, Multilateral Financing for Global Health, Foreign Aid & Corruption
5) Global Health and Justice
6) One Health
7) Health Demography: Globalization and Migration
8) Globalization and Food Security
9) Global Health Policy: The Control of Illegal Drugs
10) Climate Change and Global Health
11) Health in War, Disasters, and Emergencies
12) Global Infectious Diseases and Pandemic Policies

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Biostatistics
courses.description: This course will introduce the basic biostatistics concepts and their applications in health data analysis. Emphasis will be placed on conceptual understanding of statistical approaches to medical data rather than on theory and equations. Students will learn the importance of the correct use of statistical methods in addressing questions of public health importance. The course will enable students to develop the statistical literacy necessary to interpret the vast amounts of information they must process for decision making. The biostatistics concepts will be taught together with a user-friendly software SPSS for performing basic statistical analyses.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken -COMM3110, DSME2010,2020,2011,2021, ECON2121, GRMD2102, PHPC1015, PSYC2010, SEEM2430, SOCI2004, SPED2600, STAT2101,2102,2001 or 2006.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
| By the end of this course, student should be able to: 1. have an understanding of the fundamental concepts of probability and basic statistics. 2. apply this knowledge towards improved understanding of reports on research findings and better decision making. |
| --- |
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to descriptive statistics: Levels of measurement, measuring central tendency and variability, frequency tables.
2. Statistical Charts and Probability
3. Probability distributions: Normal, binomial
4. Sampling distributions
5. Estimation and confidence intervals
6. Hypothesis testing: t-tests
7. Hypothesis testing: two-sample tests
8. Hypothesis testing: Categorical data
9. Nonparametric tests
10. Correlation
11. Correlation (II) and Simple linear regression (I)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Theories and Concepts of Health Behaviours
courses.description: The course lays the foundation for socio-medical behavioural sciences in public health. Contents of the course include the definitions of health and health as a socially constructed concept, some important theories that have been widely used in health promotion, interdisciplinary health concepts, as well as key concepts about health promotion.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Pre-requisite: PHPC1022 or PHPC2008.
Not for students who have taken CHPR3002, 3008, 4008 or PHPC1016
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:

1. understand the definitions and social constructions of health

2. understand basic health behavioral theories and how these theories can be used to formulate strategies for health improvement programs

3. demonstrate interdisciplinary understandings on health communication, positive psychology, and patient’s responses to illness

4. understand the key concepts of the planning process for health promotion
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course Introduction, Social Construction of Health

2. Fear Appeal Approach, Health Belief Model, Introduction of group project

3. Theory of Planned Behaviors, Stages of Change Model

4. Social Cognitive Theory, Social Support and Social Network

5. Communication Theory, Diffusion of Innovations

6. Social Marketing and Health Promotion

7. Introduction to Implementation Science

8. Health Program Planning and Evaluation (I)

9. Health Program Planning and Evaluation (II)

10. Application of theories in health promotion: case example

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Epidemiology
courses.description: This course aims to introduce the fundamental concepts and principles of epidemiological methods and their applicability to the field of healthcare research. Students will grasp the knowledge about the rationale, advantages and shortcomings of different types of epidemiological studies and the basic skills needed to conduct and critically interpret the results of such studies.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken PHPC1014.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students are expected to be able to:

1. describe and differentiate the commonly used study designs in epidemiological research and appreciate the advantages and shortcomings of each.

2. describe and differentiate the commonly used sampling and data collection methods and appreciate the advantages and shortcomings of each.

3. calculate and interpret the commonly used effect measures in epidemiological research.

4. explain with examples important methodological issues such as bias in epidemiological research which may affect interpretation of results.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. (1) Introduction to the course

(2) Introduction to epidemiological research issues with discussion of common sources of health data & introduction to research ethics

2. Measures of disease occurrence, adjustment of rates

3. Introduction to descriptive studies & cross-sectional studies

4. Sampling methods

5. Cohort studies

6. Case-Control Studies

7. Confounding

7. Intervention studies (community base, clinical trial)

8. Data collection methods/ questionnaire design and item construction, creating scales, validity & reliability

9. Evaluation of diagnostic and screening tests

10. Effect modification, bias, and causal inference in epidemiology

11. Brief overview of systematic reviews

Course evaluation will be conducted at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.
Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Infectious Diseases of Public Health Importance
courses.description: The course provides an overview of the epidemiology and principles on prevention and control of infectious diseases of global and local public health importance. It covers major conventional infectious disease categories including respiratory, vector-borne, foodborne, vaccine-preventable, etc. as well as contemporary major infections including COVID-19. Biological features and characteristics, routes and risk factors for transmission, and specific public health issues on their prevention and control will be discussed. The perspectives of food safety and cancer prevention in relation to infection control will be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of new curriculum only.
Not for studens who have taken PHPC1018.
Pre-requisite: PHPC1017.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:

1. Describe and explain the spectrum, epidemiology, causative agents, risk and route of transmission of infectious diseases of global and local public health importance

2. Describe and discuss the general public health management, prevention and control strategies of these infectious diseases
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Vaccine-preventable diseases
2. Respiratory tract infections
3. HIV/AIDS and Sexually transmitted infections
4. Viral hepatitis
5. Cancers and infections
6. Foodborne infections and food safety
7. Antimicrobial resistance and gut microbiota
8. Viral hemorrhagic fever
9. Tuberculosis
10. The coronavirus infections - seasonal and emerging coronaviruses
11. Vector-borne infection
12. Prevention and control of influenza including avian flu

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Practical Skills in Literature Search and Review
courses.description: This course will prepare the public health students with basic concepts of evidence-based healthcare. They will acquire skills in forming an answerable healthcare question, conducting literature search, and critical appraisal of research findings from epidemiological studies. Students are expected to demonstrate skills in performing literature search and critical appraisal independently.

courses.description: This course is inspiring and provides students with valuable insight through interactive lectures, workshops, simulation, guest sharing, field visit, presentation, and services in a community setting. courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Health Care System Field Studies
courses.description:
This study tour is to give a great learning experience of how the health system works in other jurisdictions. With the study tour, students can gain first-hand experiences and grasp certain knowledge about the health system, its structure, governance, financing and service delivery provision in specific jurisdiction which may varies in each year depending on the site arrangement of corresponding study tour. Students will identify the strengths of the system, how it produces good outcome and what challenges it tackles in order to achieve the good health and high quality of healthcare in population. The study tour also ties policy with health system in a broader context.

Students are required to select a study topic of interest, for example, healthcare financing and universal coverage, long term care, quality of healthcare delivery, and impact of policy in population health and then to review literature, to collect information from the places visited and seminar, and to deliver a presentation in the class.

This course will be held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. Students are responsible for all travel expenses in the study tour, including air fares, accommodation, food, transportation and travel insurance.

The objectives of the course are three-fold:
(1) to offer students a field-based education in their undergraduate programs for the extension of classroom learning through direct observation, sharing and experience;(2) to deepen students’ understanding on health system in a broader context including its structure, governance, financing and service delivery provision; and
(3) to provide students a comprehensive view on local and regional public health issues in health system.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Acquire basic knowledge and practical skills on how to obtain, process and organize information in understanding how the health system work in the jurisdiction
2. Apply theoretical framework to real-world issues and scenario observed in the study tour
3. Apply critical thinking skill, written, oral communication and presentation skill to effectively synthesize a cogent argument in public health issues and challenges in health system
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Lecture on local health insurance
2. Site visit to local hospital
3. Site visit to local community-based healthcare center
4. Lecture on a healthcare topic of local concern
5. Site visit to local healthcare services of a healthcare topic of local concern

2. Leung G.M. & Bacon-Shone J. (2006). Hong Kong’s health system: reflections, perspectives and visions.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Public Health Ethics and Law
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the basic concepts of ethics and law and explore their relevance to professional and clinical public health practices. It will introduce students to the role of ethics and law in promoting and protecting public health. Case studies will be used to highlight contemporary ethical and legal issues in public health in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: PHPC1001 or UGEC1920 or MEDF1021 or UGEC2930.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students should be able to learn:

1. Understand basic ethical concepts and applications

2. Discuss contemporary ethical dilemmas in public health and health care scenarios

3. Understand basic legal terminology and sources of law in Hong Kong

4. Understand Hong Kong’s public health legislation

5. Understand the importance of ethics and law in protecting public health

6. Identify and analyze different approaches to decision-making in relation to public health dilemmas and the relevant ethics considerations

7. Demonstrate an understanding of public health as a public good in Hong Kong
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to ethics: what is it?

2. Bioethics: Origin and Current Paradigms

3. Moral theories in bioethics, Part 1

4. Moral theories in bioethics, Part 2

5. Moral theories in bioethics, Part 3

6. Moral theories, principles, and rules

7. Public health law and ethics

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Evidence Based Public Health and Healthcare
courses.description: Building on students’ skills in epidemiology and biostatistics, this module will introduce advanced concepts and skills in evidence-based public health and healthcare. Students will acquire the skills in turning public health and healthcare queries into focused questions on effectiveness, diagnostic and screening performances . Students will be equipped with skills to critically appraise the validity and generalizability of research findings, to synthesize evidence and to implement evidence into practice.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students of new curriculum only.
Not for students who have taken PHPC2014.
Pre-requisites: PHPC2015 & PHPC2017.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, student should be able to:
Master advanced skills in practicing evidence based public health and healthcare, including the formulation of focused clinical questions, critique on the validity and generalizability of evidence, synthesis of evidence, and translating knowledge into action.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Concepts in evidence based public health and healthcare
2. Critical appraisal of observational study I --- cross-sectional study
3. Critical appraisal of observational study II --- case-control study
4. Critical appraisal of observational study III --- cohort study
5. Critical appraisal of experimental study I ---randomized controlled trial
6. Critical appraisal of experimental study II --- quasi-experimental studies
7. Systematic review I --- practical skills of systematically literature search
8. Systematic review II --- acquisition and synthesis of evidence
9. Translating evidence into practice --- introduction to implementation science
10. Introduction to meta-analysis

courses.title: Practical Skills in the Public Health Management of Infectious Diseases
courses.description: This course aims to acquaint students with practical knowledge and skills for prevention and control of infectious disease from public health perspectives. It covers principles and steps on investigating and controlling different types of infectious disease outbreak in various settings including practical skills and issues in the field. Local and global perspectives on infectious disease management will be discussed.

2. Explain the principles and apply practical steps and specific methods for outbreak investigations and control

3. Interpret epidemiological data collected from the field and be able to draw appropriate conclusions and recommendations

7. Disaster and infectious disease

courses.description: This course addresses how environmental factors affect human health and what we can do to prevent or minimize the negative impacts. It examines the environmental health issues and recent development in industrialized and developing countries. It also covers risk analysis and communication, environmental health policy, and emerging environmental health problems.

2. Discuss the exposure assessment, epidemiology and toxicology methods to assess the risk of environmental exposures on human health

3. Discuss the human health effects of various environmental hazards

4. Describe the basic principles and methods of environmental monitoring

5. Discuss health outcomes linked to local environmental changes

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Work and Health
courses.description:
This course adopts a systematic approach to the study of occupational health and hygiene, and addresses both the effects of work on health and the effects of health on work. It covers the scopes and principles of occupational health and hygiene, toxicological assessment and occupational exposure limits, principles of ergonomics, occupational diseases including cancers and the relevant legislations,

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Environmental Health Field Studies
courses.description:
This field study course is supplementary to the three classroom-based courses CHPR2001, PHPC2009 and PHPC3016 on the environmental factors in public health. Students can gain first-hand experiences and grasp certain practical skills by conducting the field studies in Hong Kong, China and other areas. Environmental health is about how the environmental factors may adversely impact the public health and what we can do to prevent or minimize these impacts. By the scale, the hazards can be local (e.g., industrial and household pollution, traffic exhaust), regional (e.g., deteriorating regional air quality), or global (e.g., climate change); by the relationship to social development, the hazards can be traditional (e.g., household hygiene) or modern (e.g., new chemicals). Without field studies, the students may have difficulties in understand the broad scopes of environmental health practice. This course is to fill in this gap by conducting local and regional field studies and equipping the students with practical skills (e.g., air sampling techniques) in environmental monitoring, risk assessment and management. Students are first required to select a study topic of interest, for example air pollution and respiratory diseases, water pollution and metal industry, and social development and sustainability, and then to review literature, to collect information from the places visited, and to write up a final report.

This course will be held during term breaks under the supervision of one or more faculty members. Students are responsible for all travel expenses in the field study, including transportation, food, accommodation, and travel insurance.

The objectives of the course are three-fold: (1) to offer students a field-based education early in their undergraduate programs for the extension of classroom learning through direct observation and experience; (2) to deepen students’ understanding on relationships between environment and health, with emphasis on pollution, social development, and sustainability; and (3) to provide students a comprehensive view on local and regional public health issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite: CHPR2001 or PHPC2009 or PHPC3016
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, the students should be able to:

•Acquire basic knowledge and practical skills on how to obtain, process and organize information in environmental monitoring, risk assessment and management
•Apply scientific methods and public health theories to real-world issues and scenario observed in the field study
•Apply critical thinking skill, written, oral communication and presentation skill to effectively synthesize a cogent argument in environmental health
courses.course_syllabus: Lecture on local pollution and health problems; Site visit to local industry , e.g. plastic factory, cement plan; Lecture on water pollution and health sustainability in urban areas; Site visit to local automatic ambient air monitoring stations; Site visit to Centers for Disease Control (CDC) and local hospitals Lecture on health impact of hazardous waste; Site visit to local hazardous waste management centre

courses.description: Should health care be privatized? Is health insurance bad to your health? Who should pay the enormous cost of rare disease care? Finally, should I getting married or stay as single? All these questions are related to health economics (yes, even the last one). The course will introduce the key features in health economics analysis, such as demand and supply, equity vs efficiency, and cost-effectives analysis, a tool to priorities health programs to efficiently maximize resources allocation. The course will also introduce healthcare financing and its impact on health care system. Students will be able to identify different models of healthcare financing around the world.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Health Promotion in Practice - Social Marketing
courses.description: This course aims to equip students with practical skills to apply health promotion concepts and methodology to resolve real-life public health problems. The course will give a deep examination of commonly used behavioural health models and teach practical skills in designing, implementing and evaluating behavioural intervention programmes. It covers areas such as formative research, scoping, implementation process, frameworks of health promotion, health communication skills, methods of designing and disseminating health messages, use of appropriate health settings and strategies for community involvement. Social marketing will be used as the main framework, integrating with general health promotion methods such as scoping, setting, behavioural change techniques, health communication and evaluation methods. The course will also provide hands-on training on the complete process of health promotion programme development.

3. Apply skills commonly used in health promotion such as needs assessment, engagement of stakeholders, program planning, implementation, dissemination and marketing, and evaluation.

courses.description: Qualitative research in public health has become more important and is rapidly expanding. By adopting qualitative research approaches, in-depth social-cultural ideas in public health issues, which cannot be explained by quantitative methods alone, can be explained and explored. Obtaining the knowledge and skills of qualitative research methods enables students to better examine contemporary health problems in context.

courses.title: Applied Economics Evaluation in Health Care
courses.description: Economic evaluation is a comparative science in which health interventions are compared in terms of both their costs and their effectiveness. In this course we will have a brief review of the basic principles, potential roles and limitations of economic evaluation. The course covers use of decision trees and state transition models, involving practical sessions in which participants develop, populate, and analyse cost-effectiveness models by using Excel. On completion of the course, students will have the necessary knowledge and materials to undertake a basic health economic evaluation; to explore methods for more complex evaluations; and to critically review the conduct and validity of presented or published evaluations.

2. Describe and discuss issues on measuring and valuing resource allocation in health care

3. Plan, undertake and conduct economic evaluation of an actual health intervention

4. Present output from economic evaluations, interpret its results, and discuss how results should be applied in priority setting

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Traditional, Complementary and Integrative Medicine
courses.description:
With increasing interest and usage of traditional, complementary and integrative medicine (TCIM) worldwide, it is recognized that public education is a key to promote safe and effective use of TCIM in the community. The World Health Organization Traditional Medicine Strategy 2014-23 has specified the strategic direction of: 1. Ensuring consumers of TCIM can make informed choices about self-health care. 2. Promoting proper use of TCIM products and services.
This course aims to serve as an education intervention for achieving these two goals. Students will be introduced the basic theory and practice of popular forms of TCIM, and more importantly, be equipped with skills for assessing claims on the effectiveness and safety of various TCIM interventions. Finally, course will also briefly introduce the policy and regulatory aspects of TCIM in the modern healthcare system.

After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Demonstrate an understanding of the underlying concepts and practice of popular traditional complementary and integrative medicine (TCIM) modalities.

2. Be able to describe the utilization patterns of TCIM in different populations and its implications on regulation and policy

3. Be able to interpret and appraise claims on the effectiveness and safety of TCIM modalities

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Introduction to Data Science in Health and Medicine
courses.description: Have you read in the news about certain environmental exposures that could be risk factors for our health and wondered how these large studies were conducted and analyzed? Have you come across a presentation with professional scientific figures and wondered how they were created? Data science, together with biostatistics and epidemiology, comprises the core competencies to answer these questions. This course is designed for public health and biomedical students to understand the concepts and practices of data science, as well as to develop skills in querying epidemiological data to make informed decisions for health and biomedical studies. It will discuss various aspects of data processing, analysis, and visualization techniques in the R computing environment and the use of modern coding approach to streamline the progress from mining data to presenting findings. Students will be introduced to modern data-driven techniques to identify important non-genetic factors. The course will also cover advanced topics, including omics and precision medicine, artificial intelligence (AI)/ machine learning (ML) in biomedical decision-making, and investigations with real-world data. Students will conduct a guided project analyzing health survey data.

After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Understand basic coding in R computing environment
2. Apply modern coding concepts and practices through the tidyverse packages
3. Process raw data to prepare it for statistical analysis
4. Present and discuss results using the most suitable visualization and interactive methods
5. Apply the coding skills learned in the course to their own projects
6. Have the capability to independently learn and apply R packages not covered in the course
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Data science & R
2. Working with RStudio
3. Hypothesis testing in R
4. Linear modeling in R
5. Acting with tidyverse
6. Big data and complex health survey
7. Multiomics and data-driven analysis
8. Special topic: artificial intelligence (AI)/ machine learning (ML) and biomedical decision making
9. Special topic: epidemiologic investigation with real-world data

courses.description: This is an introductory course on the management, organisational structure and behaviour, and leadership of health and healthcare organisations. This course will use lectures, case studies, and team-based learning to teach students about basic theories, skills, and concepts about managing people and situations in various healthcare and health-related settings. In addition to introducing students to how such organisations work on a business level, this course also emphasises on developing their leadership skills, working in a team, and communication skills which are necessary for future innovators in health.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Gender and Age-Related Healthcare
courses.description: This course examines the interaction between gender and health. The course will utilize a life course framework to discuss public health issues across the life span including women of childbearing age, infants, children, adolescents, working adults and elderly. Broad topics will include gender roles, gender analysis, gender inequalities in health, empowerment, teen health, HIV, LGBT issues, reproductive health, sex workers, domestic workers and elderly abuse.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite:PHPC1001 or MEDF1021 or UGEC1920 or UGEC2930.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the course, the students will be expected to:

1. Understand the concept of life-course approach in dealing with healthcare problems, in particular issues related to child and adolescent health,

reproductive and general health for men and women, and international gender-related health.

2. Describe epidemiological differences in morbidity and mortality between men and women.

3. Identify gender differences in healthy behaviors, health seeking behavior, access and use of health services from the client and health care

provider's perspectives, and discuss the impact of these differences.

4. Describe other gender-based influences on wellness and heath care utilization, such as gender-based violence.

5. Describe how gender equity and rights approach can be incorporated into sexual and reproductive health programming
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to gender Socio-determinants of women and men's health

2. Gender roles, Gender Analysis and Gender mainstreaming

3. Teen Health: Eating disorders

4. Gender equality

5. Teen health: Teen Pregnancy

6. Health issues for men: HIV and STD's

7. Teen Health: Compensated Dating

8. Lesbian, Bisexual, Gay and Transsexual Individuals

9. Reproductive health issues for men and women: Contraception and termination

10. Vulnerable populations: Sex workers

11. Vulnerable populations: Domestic workers and Trafficking

12. Gender based violence: Elder abuse, domestic violence?
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Course evaluation will be conducted in mid-term and at the end of the term in form of close-end and open-end questions.

Continuous feedback will be collected via discussion forum on course websites.

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Digital Health and Entrepreneurship

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408
William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408

courses.description: Our students will be introduced to digital health, data analytics and their use and impact on public health. They will explore the implementation of computational technologies on healthcare, including electronic health portal, mobile health, and artificial intelligence applications. They will acquire practical skills on health data management and data presentation. Moreover, the key concepts and latest developments of entrepreneurship on healthcare technology will be introduced, and students will learn the skills of conducting pitch presentation for a healthcare product.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. describe the concepts and recent developments of digital health
2. describe with examples the potential use of health technology for entrepreneurship
3. conduct oral presentation that describe potential health products using business models
4. analyse and critique the usefulness of healthcare technology using an evidence-based approach
courses.course_syllabus:

2. The Fundamental Concepts on Entrepreneurship
3. Essential skills of Pitching Presentation
4. Discussion the Challenges of Pitching Presentation
5. Electronic Health records
6. Data Sharing Regulation and Data Protection
7. Skills on Data Visualization
8. Basic Concepts on Machine Learning and its Application
9. Artificial Intelligence on Healthcare
10. Healthcare Devices and Platforms

11. Evaluation of Digital Health Products

12. Entrepreneurship case study

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Medical Sociology

meetings.instructor:
Dr. WANG Jingxuan, 
Professor YANG Xue

courses.description: This course introduces students to major perspectives, theories, and methods in the field of sociology of health and medicine. We consider a variety of social, political, economic, and cultural factors to understand the topics of health, illness, and medicine instead of simply looking at the biological phenomena and medical knowledge. We will explore questions such as: What are the social meanings of illness? What is social production of health and illness? How do social ties and social capital affect health? How does the social environment interact with genes to influence health? What is medicalization and what are possible consequences of medicalization? How should health care systems be organized? In this course, we will examine some of these issues in the contexts of Chinese societies, such as mainland China and Hong Kong, and also offer comparative perspectives.
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to medical sociology
2. Gender, sexuality, and health
3. Social stratification and health
4. Ethnicity, immigration, and health
5. Social change and new challenges in the digital age
6. Neighborhood influences on health
7. Social capital, social cohesion, and health
8. Genes, social environment, and health
9. Illness behavior and illness experience
10. Social construction of health and illness I
11. Social construction of health and illness II

courses.description: Students will conduct a supervised primary research project in a chosen field of public health using quantitative or qualitative research method. In this module, students are expected to provide a research protocol and prepare for data collection.

After completing this course, students should be able to:

1. Study a public health problem by formulating relevant research hypotheses

2. Employ an appropriate design for the study

5. Draw out the study implication to public health

courses.subject: PHPC
courses.title: Public Health Practicum
courses.description: Students will be assigned to one of the collaborating public health service providers, including (but not limited to) government departments, non-governmental organizations and the private sectors, based on their declared preference. Prior to the engagement of practicum, each student must discuss his or her potential role and responsibilities with the site supervisor. All fieldwork can only be initiated after the prior approval of the course coordinator and site supervisor. Students are required to complete a minimum of 100 hours of fieldwork under the supervision of site supervisor.

Experiential Learning Course
Internship
courses.academic_group: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.academic_org: JC Sch of Pub Health Prim Care
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
1. Apply academic theories and acquired skills to community-based programme or service or evaluation in a real-life setting
2. Understand the vision, missions, values, and the populations served by the designated organization
3. Communicate public health concepts clearly in verbal and written forms and familiarize with multi-disciplinary public health practice
4. Expand their networks with key stakeholders of public health
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Practicum plan presentation
2. Fieldwork practicum in a designated organization (at least 100 hours)
3. Poster presentation
